greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Factorial eigentriangle: A119502 * (A051295 *0^(n-k); 0<=k<=n
comment: Triangle read by rows, termwise product of (n-k)! (i.e factorial decrescendo,
A119502) and the INVERT transform of the factorials (A051925) prefaced by a 1:
The operation (A051295 * 0^(n-k) with A051295 prefaced with a 1 = an infinite lower triangular matrix with (1, 1, 2, 5, 15, 54, 235,...) in the main diagonal and the rest zeros.
Row sums = the INVERT transform of the factorials, A051295: (1, 2, 5, 15, 54, 235, 1237,...).
Sum of n-th row terms = rightmost term of next row; e.g. ( 6 + 2 + 2 + 5) = 15.

With offset 1 for n and k, T(n,k) counts permutations of [n] that contain a 132 pattern only as part of a 4132 pattern by position k of largest entry n. Example: T(5,3)=4 counts 34512, 34521, 43512, 43521. - _David Callan_, Nov 21 2011
A production matrix M for the reversal of the triangle is follows: M =
...Take powers of M, extracting the top row, getting: (1), (1, 1), (2, 1, 2), (5, 2, 2, 6),... - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jul 21 2016
formula: The operation uses A119502 prefaced with a 1 = (1, 1, 2, 5, 15, 54, 235,...); i.e. the right border of the triangle.
example: First few rows of the triangle =
Example: Row 3 = (6, 2, 2, 5) = termwise products of row 3 terms of triangle A119502 (6, 2, 1, 1) and the first four terms of (1, 1, 2, 5,...) = (6*1, 2*1, 1*2, 1*5).
results.author: _Gary W. Adamson_, Sep 06 2008
